Welcome to the ECB Bravadorado, it's better to answer your questions here than to the "Holy smiting Dragon's" thread, so let's begin.

First you need to answer some questions about the environment you will be playing these builds, be it modules or a persistent world? That alone makes a big difference.

Secondly you need to decide if you want your Paladin to have the ability to inflict Holy Smites, because a "Smiter" is a huge investment in the build and requires many sacrifices to be made in order to make him/her a one-hit-wonder. Generally speaking a "Smiter" is way more viable in a module's environemnt than in a persistent world with restricted resting because he/she can inflict those powerful hits only up to 3 times per rest.

Paladins in Neverwinter Nights are powerful offensive warriors contrary to some beliefs, with the addition of Divine Might & Shield those holy warriors can both inflict and take some serious punishment. Their spells are also quite potent giving them the ability to rise their "Attack Bonus" to very high levels. A properly build Paladin is a force to be reckoned with even without the addition of other classes.

Some possible Paladin builds that keep true to the "Warrior" aspect are investing a bit into the "Fighter" class in order to augment their damage with the addition of "Epic Weapon Specialization". A true and tested such build is (Paladin 26/ Fighter 4/ Champion of Torm 10). These kind of builds usually go for high AB and Dmg and possible Devastating Critical without investing in the Smiting aspect. They are very powerful non the less. Another option is to replace the fighter with monk instead in order to gain evasion, use of monk gear and higher armour class via the "full tamble" skill of the monk. You lose the EWS however.

One last thing that differenciates the Nwn1 from Nwn2. You can only have 30 levels in the second game instead of 40 as in the original.

Consider these and i will wait your answers before proceeding to good recommendation for your needs.

The full campaign in Nwn1 goes up to 27th to 28th level. There are only a handful of modules that go beyond that range, because DnD in general breaks down at epic levels. This is a fundamental flaw in the original DnD rules and not of Nwn's. Having said that, the quality and enjoyment you get from a module has little to do with it's maximum level. You are right to want to look at level 30 sub-forum builds, these are optimized better for that range and in general don't wait to power up at the end of the build. So, have a look at these builds in there and see if you like something, if not then we can make a Paladin suited to your needs, unfortunately the less levels you have to work upon the harder is to get many things in one build as you have guessed by now. The Holy Avenger sword is a very good (if not the best) sword that you can get in pre-epic levels, of course since Nwn1 goes up to 40th level there are much better options out there once you get past that point, do not worry you will find them out in time.

The other option you have is to go for the Aielund Saga. This is a series of modules that were made after the official campaign and they are generally considered to be the best of the best out there. Having played them, i totally agree with that, Aielund makes the official campaign to look almost childish in comparison but i would still not skip on the SoU => HoTU campaign. There is much to learn there and it has a sufficiently epic scope by itself. It is also much easier than Aielund or other modern modules and will serve better as an introductory module for you.

Alongside the SoU => HoTU campaign there is also another and very classic module that is ideal for a Paladin character. That is the "Lord of Terror - The Diablo Campaign" and it is basically a faithful remake of the Diablo 1 game in the Nwn1 engine complete with sounds and story. You can find more information about that in the "Modules" section. This is also a module that finishes at about the same (27th -28th) level as the HoTU so if you decide you want a character optimized for that range you have multiple options to select from.

Now, having narrowed down what level about your character is about to end his carrier and the environment that you are going to play him/her, then we can make some critical decisions about the build.
First of all we can exclude "Great Smite" from your build since this is too costly and comes very late to the build to actually matter. You will still be able to deal your regular smites however, so all is not lost.
Secondly we will have to exclude "Devastating Critical" from the build as well, since that also comes at the earliest of 24th level (thereabout) and in many modules is either not allowed (aielund) or nerfed to the ground because of the type of enemies that you are going to face (Sands of Fate).
Good thing that a properly build Paladin has no need from these two to deal with his enemies eh? His combat spells and his Divine Abilities more than make up for the loss of those. Your Paladin's abilities can be further augmented with the aid of Champion of Torm class. CoT has a "Divine Wrath" ability that is based on Charisma and since your hero is going to be looking "Heavenly good" he is a natural choice for this combo. As a natural third choice comes the Fighter to gives us his Weapon Specialization ability but in truth we do not need him because we are going to do a lot of damage with our buffs and divine might, so instead we can opt for Monk. Apart from giving our Holy warrior a more sophisticated look he can gives us better armour class as well. You see Monk can use some special equipment that normal warriors cannot use (Sun Soul boots) and with him being profficient in the use of "Tumble skill" we can expect at least 5 more AC till 27th level. What best Monk will also gives free cleave as a feat and the much needed evasion.

As you see, i am advising a (Paladin/ Monk/ CoT) for your Holy warrior and for a good reason. Forget "Torm" in the name of the class, it can be any other God's name as you RP it. The class is very good to combine with your Paladin, same with Monk or Fighter. But i am afraid i talk too much and i might confuse you with explanations you do not need to know from now. Give it a thought and decide what you are going to play then give us your feedback and we will make the best we can.

Having had an albeit cursory look at the build you cite on the wiki, and not a Pally player, I'm not over-impressed by it, but I'll confine my comments more to the Monk areas, where I feel more comfortable (and Empyre and Valerfor will correct any mistakes I make, I'm sure).

The reasons the build starts with Monk are entirely practical ones. Apart from getting the Cleave and Evasion feats for free right at the beginning, you get twice the amount of skills points to allocate at level 1 (admittedly only 16 rather than 8), and you get the 4 points in Tumble straight away - effectively saving you a further 4 points - in what is a skill-starved build in any case (only 137). However, I can see a good case for putting it back to level 2, because you'd still get the free feats then and you'd be able to take 5 points in Tumble for +1AC. Regardless, I think only 1 level of Monk is missing a trick - at least 2 levels would be better (I'd probably go for more, but that's just me), with the final one coming late on in the build so you can max that Tumble AC bonus (up to +8) without it costing you twice the amount of skill points.

The Sun Soul boots (Monk-specific, given you won't have UMD) are excellent. If I remember correctly, in the OC and SoU they cap at +5, but I seem to recall +7s in HotU. Anyway, just focusing on the +5 boots, they not only give +5 to AC but also +2 to DEX, which is another +1 to AC, so that's +6 in total, which is immense. There are indeed other perma-haste items out there (a chain mail comes to mind), and Rizolvir (a smith in the Underdark and again in Cania in HotU) can add perma-haste to a weapon for you.

Are you really asking for a worse build, just for the sake of appearances? Great Cleave will tie you into mob fighting while mages and clerics wail on you from afar and Overwhelming Crit only adds a smattering of damage to the build, and is only available in epic levels in any case.
